Comment: Hey all! Just a quick annotation over lunch; nothing too in-depth but I thought this would be an enjoyable game to take a look at. Many thanks to my opponent!
The King's Gambit! One of my favorite openings on both sides of the board. It's very rare to see a dull game in this opening.
The King's Gambit! One of my favorite openings on both sides of the board. It's very rare to see a dull game in this opening.
"The refutation of any gambit begins by accepting it." Not that I intend to refute the KG, but at least Mr. Fischer agrees with me that 2...exf4 is best.

All very by-the-book. I should mention that I played several games against this opponent; this was one of the later ones and the opening was played quite rapidly as we'd already played it out a couple of times at this point.

All very by-the-book. I should mention that I played several games against this opponent; this was one of the later ones and the opening was played quite rapidly as we'd already played it out a couple of times at this point.
Bolstering g5 in preparation for developing the KN. This is still standard play in lines where Black seeks to hold on to the gambit pawn.

The first game we played, White played 7.Bxf7+?! in this position. I ended up with a crushing lead, and I think this time he was feeling somewhat too cautious. More common are 7.h4, 7.g3, or simply 7.O-O.

The first game we played, White played 7.Bxf7+?! in this position. I ended up with a crushing lead, and I think this time he was feeling somewhat too cautious. More common are 7.h4, 7.g3, or simply 7.O-O.

The first game we played, White played 7.Bxf7+?! in this position. I ended up with a crushing lead, and I think this time he was feeling somewhat too cautious. More common are 7.h4, 7.g3, or simply 7.O-O.
Ready to deploy to g6, f5, or maybe c6, depending on how things unfold.
I probably would have castled first, but this is still fine. It does make f5 an enticing spot for Black's Knight, however.

I'm not sure how to feel about this. On the one hand, it invites Black to bottle up his forces with 9...c6, making development slightly more difficult. On the other hand, it doesn't accomplish a whole lot, and Black's QN frequently ends up aiding on the kingside via d7 anyway, so this check may not accomplish much of anything.

I'm not sure how to feel about this. On the one hand, it invites Black to bottle up his forces with 9...c6, making development slightly more difficult. On the other hand, it doesn't accomplish a whole lot, and Black's QN frequently ends up aiding on the kingside via d7 anyway, so this check may not accomplish much of anything.
I always feel especially daring castling kingside in this opening.
I always feel especially daring castling kingside in this opening.
I always feel especially daring castling kingside in this opening.
This Bishop doesn't have many prospects--one of the reasons White usually tries to break up Black's kingside pawn chain earlier than this.
Preventing the Bishop from getting trapped (by 12...b5 13.Bb3 a4).
Preventing the Bishop from getting trapped (by 12...b5 13.Bb3 a4).
This is an ugly spot for the Bishop, but Black intends to reposition it after dealing with the e-pawn. For now, the Bishop serves merely as a blockade.
Preparing for queenside castling.
Finally arriving on this comfortable outpost--with the threat of leaping to g3 and winning a crucial exchange as the game heats up and lines begin to open.
? Overlooking Black's threat.
Intending to assist pushed on f6 or c5.
Intending to assist pushed on f6 or c5.

Transferring forces to the kingside. White is firmly behind now, so he has to see if he can make Black pay for his overextended kingside pawns.

Black responds with a queenside counter.
?! Questionable at best, but Black really wants to break up White's center and let his Bishops get into the action.
